evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root

slot_statements.availability: Communication/coordination breakdown among crew is evident and documented in the Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_baseline_t1_early dataset.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The explanation of communication/coordination breakdown among crew withstands potential counterarguments or alternative explanations within the Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_baseline_t1_early scope, maintaining its validity as a root cause.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with the key features observed in the Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_baseline_t1_early data, such as timing, involved personnel, and situational context.

node.statement: Communication/coordination breakdown among crew is evident and documented in the Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_baseline_t1_early dataset.

assumptions: That the overrun beyond the TRP and collision with the barrier resulted from communication/coordination breakdown rather than other causes.
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination preventing the overrun, or if mechanical failure caused the incident instead.

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence (H1-H5) documents crew communication and coordination during pushback, including a trainee stopping and instructor taking over, yet the aircraft overruns the tug release point and hits a barrier, indicating a communication/coordination breakdown consistent with the claim.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether procedural deviation or communication breakdown is primary cause; no explicit crew communication errors detailed.

The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

node.statement: Crew members were physically present and reachable during the operation

defeaters: If evidence showed crew members were not physically present or unreachable during the operation
If communication was completely absent or failed despite physical presence

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1, H2, and H3 directly indicate that crew members (tug instructor, trainee driver, headset operator, wingman) were physically present and reachable during the operation, supporting the claim.
outcome.uncertainty_source: none
